title: Before 1 September 2020, will Cameroon's Paul Biya and/or Togo's Faure Gnassingbé cease to be the president of their respective countries?
preds:
Given the short time to the timeline of this challenge , I am proposing both to be inlace 1 September.
I would give Gnassingbe (Togo) given his relative youth, progressive economic (if corrupt) policies somewhat longer.
Biya (Cameroon) is 87 with an repressive administration, increasing poverty and terrorism and therefore a limited time as president.
Covid-19 will have a distraction for insurrection, although Biya would be susceptible to succumbing to the disease. Paul Biya (Cameroon) was born 13 February 1933 and is currently 87 years old.
56% poor living in Northern regions
Between 2007 and 2014, poverty increased 12% (8.1 M).
Boko Haram is a problem in the North.
Corruption ranks 152 out of 182.
Cameroon’s ruling party is using the pandemic to settle scores and punish the opposition.
Country is not stable. https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/cameroon/overview
https://www.heritage.org/index/country/cameroon
https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/05/14/covid-19-brings-out-governments-ugly-side-cameroon
https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/central-africa/cameroon/130-cameroon-worsening-anglophone-crisis-calls-strong-measures  Faure Gnassingbe was born 6 June 1966 and currently 54 years old.
 He inherited the Presidency from his Father Gnassingbe Evadema in 2005
Won 4th Term in February 2020 election.
Tenth poorest country in the world according to IMF.
Togo has had a GDP 5% growth rate, from which , it is alleged, the Gnassingbe family profits from. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-41174005  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/02/togo-president-faure-gnassingbe-wins-fourth-term-landslide-200224050830042.html  https://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/28582/it-will-take-more-than-an-election-to-oust-faure-gnassingbe-in-togo  https://www.heritage.org/index/country/togo  https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/west-central-africa/card/EC2KKfjxtZ/  140 ranking in freedom of economic index
1.7% unemployment. (Other accounts are 6.9%).
5% GDP growth rate.
2% inflation (2018)
National Poverty rate 55.1% 
Labour 65% rural Can be construed as political stable that is due to corruption and manipulation.
Covid-19 has resulted in 3%  drop in GDP
Macron has offered funds to help in pandemic which shows support from a western government.
The Government has made efforts to assist the informal employment sector.
Leaving 1% chance given Biya's age, otherwise  seeing either leaders ceasing to be pres is unlikely.

Ok I see nothing on Biya health. Controversy that Biya’s daughter opened wig shop in Los Angeles, USA. Some Special Forces groups going to anglophone areas are dissatisfied with having to go there as opposed to the group that protects Biya. I will go with crowd on this but keep an eye on his military.
Extremely unlikely. Covid-19 has dictators strengthening their grip. At the same time, should they succumb to Covid-19, there will be change.

Given Biya’s age and how he was missing in April it is hard to give no the 98% consensus. Since it is a short time to the end of this question and I can find no negative information on Biya’s health I will go a long way in that direction.

Death from COVID of Biya seems the most likely possibility for him to be removed from office [1]. There is little news on Gnassingbé newer than Feb, so he is likely in a stable position. 1% for COVID against Biya. [1] https://africa.cgtn.com/2020/06/27/cameroons-president-biya-under-pressure-over-human-rights/

President Biya is the most vulnerable of the two men. While Cameroon has one of the best economies on the African continent, falling oil prices, a world wide recession resulting in reduced demand for Cameroon's natural resources, and the COVID19 pandemic have negatively impacted the country's economic status. Discontent and conflict between the English and French speaking regions weighs heavily on the President as well.  President Biya's age and questionable health prior to even factoring in his risk level with COVID19 increase the possibility that he will no longer be able to serve as President for an extended period. President Gnassingbe benefits from wide support despite the extremely poor economic conditions in Togo. Supporters most likely believe he provides political stability at a time when the country has been attempting to improve infrastructure and increase employment opportunities.
Both seem safe, not loved, but autocratically safe.

Ok...Biya in power 37 years is 87 years old and we are in a coronavirus pandemic. I better raise his being out. Faure? https://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/28582/it-will-take-more-than-an-election-to-oust-faure-gnassingbe-in-togo
There does not appear to be any movement in this space.
No news is good news for these leaders staying in power. I'll forecast no change by Sept.

Much speculation has surrounded Biya’s health lately especially now during the pandemic, not to mention that at 87 he’s Africa’s oldest head of state and government. His absence from public life is exacerbated by the previous four decade rule where he was mostly front and center. In Cameroon’s English speaking north, a practical break away state exists in the form of Ambazonia. Since March this conflict has been on hold due to the pandemic, but an insurgency is always anyways an inherent risk in a multi-decade autocratic rule. At his age he’s much more likely to simply die in office at this point.

Rumors continue to run rampant regarding Biya, with continued political pressure to step down or otherwise remove him [1]. There is video of him from April 8th with the French ambassador, so he appears to be alive [1].  Gnassingbe recently arrested the opposition leader, but there doesn't seem to to be enough of a movement to move him out [2]. Of the two, Biya seems more vulnerable.  [1] https://www.theafricareport.com/26668/cameroon-alive-with-conspiracy-theories-on-paul-biyas-health/
[2] https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/togo-bishops-decry-arrest-of-opposition-leader-35658

https://www.journalducameroun.com/en/cameroon-president-biya-cancels-labour-day-national-unity-day-celebrations-due-to-covid-19/
Biya probably not losing job during crisis. Keep checking.

Just by virtue of age, there is a chance of Paul Biya dying in the next six months, [1]. He's a prime target for C-19, and he is notably absent, [4], but does appear to still be alive, [5]  Gnassingbe is young enough for premature death not to be a determining factor, and he appears to have a solid hold on power. [2] Crises like the coronavirus tend to help dictators not undermine them - they justify repressive measures and they limit focus on the dictator.[3] [1] https://www.finder.com/life-insurance/odds-of-dying
[2] https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2020/feb/21/togo-has-long-been-mired-in-political-crisis-and-elections-wont-change-that
[3] https://africanarguments.org/2020/04/21/dictatorships-love-lockdown-coronavirus-togo/
[4] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/cameroon-paul-biya-mystery-coronavirus/2020/04/16/9bdd4172-7ff8-11ea-8de7-9fdff6d5d83e_story.html
[5] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-16/cameroon-president-reappears-amid-rumors-about-his-health

Due to corona virus it is to be expected that they have to be in their respective countries. Likelyhood of becoming ill will be significant, that means increased risk to die. Additionally the situation in those countries will worsen significantly due to the health crisis. That will increase public anger about leadership.
I'll follow @fisherdbus and assume there is a chance that Cameroon makes a change.
Covid-19. Paul Biya is part of the group of high risk. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Biya

Hattip @LokiOdinevich for insights and reference. 
"Sheltering in place" at the Intercontinental in Geneva is the most likely situtaiton for Biya.
Cameroon now reports 730 covid-19 cases with 10 deaths - the third highest in Africa.

> It isn’t unprecedented for Biya to be unseen or silent during critical moments in the life of the country. Even recent widespread rumors of his demise on social media have not forced his hand. His aides and supporters have described this phenomenon as “presidential silence” and have often argued that “his attitude is a sign of maturity and wisdom.” Source: https://qz.com/africa/1835147/cameroon-president-biya-is-absent-as-coronavirus-cases-spike/
No news April 3  Cameroon = 246 & Togo = 39 Covid-19
With elections over and covid-19 at top of mind, doubtful much else will happen before Sept.

http://www.rfi.fr/en/africa/20200228-biyas-party-maintains-grip-parliament-cameroon-election-results-announced
There are rumors Biya died but other than ge is 87 and in isolation there is no confirmation of death.?
https://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/28582/it-will-take-more-than-an-election-to-oust-faure-gnassingbe-in-togo
March 25 Togo = 23 & Cameroon =70 covid-19 cases are ramping slowly. Not clear if it will be a factor.
March 22 Togo = 16 & Cameroon =40 covid-19 cases could start impact senior leaders.
crisis's tend to show the best of most people
Togo = 16 and Cameroon = 27 covid-19 cases could start impact senior leaders.
March 20 covid-19 cases Cameroon=20 & Togo=9 and growing daily.
Cameroon now has 13 covid-19 cases. Togo has only 1.
Cameroon now reporting 10 active covid-19 cases. Not clear where the epicenter is, but this is troubling for a small state with an aged leader.
Realigning my forecast based on no news just revised thinking.

Paul Biya is an 87 year old male. In the UK, 1 in 6 males die before their 88th birthday. He has access to high level healthcare as a head of state/ wealthy individual, which bumps this down a bit (lets say 1/10).  Mr Gnassingbé has won a fourth term, and despite protests, nothing yet indicates any threat to his rule.
Shaving my forecast based on no real data.
Togo election has come and gone with no real challenge to Gnassingbe, so I'm trimming B accordingly.

Updating for passage of time based on my previous calculations. For Biya likelihood of death between now and September is now 6/12 x 10.8% = roughly 5%. An extra month has passed since my last estimate so reducing estimate he is removed from power by 1% to 4%. Total 9% chance he's removed from office.  For Gnassingbé, given passage of time, reducing by 1% the probability he's removed from office. Probability he's removed from office now = 4% from 5%.  Because of rounding in my calculations from last time, the Gnassingbé remains unchanged at 4% despite my comment above from moving from 5% to 4%.
Trimming B further as Togo's election wraps up with African Union endorsement and no signs of serious social unrest. Will cut again soon if that holds.

Trimming  A by one for passage of time, and trimming B by 2 on Gnassingbe's election win. That win was expected, but some of the probability I had here was to cover the unlikely event that he lost. The opposition is protesting the results, but that is almost pro forma in elections like these nowadays, so I don't see it as an informative event.
Slight shift towards Biya, otherwise same o same o.
basically all death risk for Biya. V low probability of mass election violence forcing the Togo guy out.
No reason to think they will step down
Paul Biya is 87 years old - finder.com says you have about 12% of dying per annum at that age. In addition, Paul has a history of illness allegedly. Otherwise reges vivant.
Don't know enough about the places

Nudging up slightly on my forecast for Biya exiting office as legislative elections wind down in Cameroon with all of the expected noise: landslide win for ruling party, opposition boycott and allegations of fraud, some violence in separatist regions (see link below). Results are supposed to be announced on March 1, so if we're going to see much (new) drama in Cameroon before this question closes, there's a good chance it will happen then. https://allafrica.com/stories/202002140197.html In all cases, though, the most likely path for Biya to leave office in the next six months is by death. In the U.S., the average 86-year-old male has an 11% chance of dying before turning 87 (per SSA actuarial life tables), so that's where most of my 8% for Biya is coming from.

Affirming prior forecast, but taking this opportunity to share One Earth Future Foundation's inaugural Election-Related Violence Intelligence System (ELVIS) report, which covers both Cameroon and Togo. https://medium.com/the-die-is-forecast/february-2020-election-violence-risk-briefing-d03d56bc5bff As you'll see if you follow that link, both countries have elections soon, and the algorithm indicates that both are likely to see election-related violence. That's consistent with my priors, though, so I'm not making any changes to the forecast yet. Instead, I will probably wait to see how those processes go and update once the dust settles (or not).

When it comes to Paul Biya He will most likely stay president of Cameroon given the fact that the election this year is only for the parliament. The only way that I can see him not remain in office is if he dies which is a probable scenario given that he is 86 years old and continues to have health issues 
When it comes to Gnassingbé He will also most likely stay in power as well because the government has already killed protesters who wanted a term limit so the protesters do not have the force to combat them. Also given the fact his family has been in power since the 1960s and that his family has de facto control of both the constitutional court and the  Independent National Electoral Commission it is unlikely given the current circumstances that he will be ousted as president anytime soon.
https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2019/togo
https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2019/cameroon
https://www.cameroonintelligencereport.com/biyas-health-panic-in-yaounde/
Adjusting estimate for Biya up slightly on @boardri's point about base rate mortality.
Readjusting. The baseline for possibility for Biya’s health is valid but due to geopolitical reasons cited before I am not going to put so much on no.
Hattip @boardri for stating the position so eloquantly. He convinced me to swap probablities.
Justice Ginsburg is still creaking. The old guys will hang in there.

Both have very strong grips on power with all institutions in both nations, as well as security forces, fully supporting the presidents.  Biya is older and in poorer health. Probability of a 86 year old dying within one year in a Western country is 10.8%. Using UK mortality rate as proxy. Using western mortality rates due to the wealth of Biya. Only 7 months until the September deadline so taking 7/12 x 10.8% for probability of death for Biya = roughly 6%. Even though he is apparently in poor health he is propped up by supporters and his government’s power appears almost absolute. Adding 5% to the 6% probability of natural death to take account of possibility for removal from office. Total chance of him not being President by September =11%. Gnassingbé is younger, so not including a probability for natural death as its almost insignificant. 5% probability that he’s removed from power. Again, almost complete control of all institutions and security forces within the country. This also make loss of the election small (if the election happens at all, a number in recent years were regularly postponed).

To be honest, I will be paying more close attention to the results of these "elections"; as I have (mostly intuitive, but somewhat influenced by past events) idea that the question will become "how long will they remain in power" after they "win", as elections like that have a tendency to galvanise opposition.

Paul Biya is 87 years old. He won in 2018 and a Presidential term is 7 years. There is supposed to be Parliamentary elections in Feb 2020. They were delayed before and the Anglophone area is trying to break away and presenting somewhat if an armed conflict. Biya is backed by France who has a lot of business there. The young, 25% of population, are under 25 and do nit like him. https://actucameroun.com/2020/02/03/chimamanda-ngozi-adichie-paul-biya-est-au-pouvoir-depuis-ma-naissance-cest-ridicule/
It is said since 1992 he has won by corrupt means. Upshot is country is unstable and he may be forced to step down.
Faure Gnassingbé Is running for 4th five year term. He won by 59% of vote in 2015 and protests after thru 2019 were crushed. Do not see him losing grip on power.

Moving from my bland forecast to one that has been informed by @ulfelder and @Gjlewis insight and research.
Given the remaining 7 month time window  - probabliites seem low for much action.
Bumping up my estimate of Gnassingbe's risk of exit a bit in response to link posted by @Gjlewis, and estimate of joint probability a hair with it.

Revising thanks to @ulfelder helping me read what I should have read before (esp. re. no presidential election in Cameroon). The chief variation is I'm slanting more towards Gnassingbe losing power, although this is essentially based on tea-leaves re. recent protests and opinion polling over term limits. (The best overview I could find is here: https://africacenter.org/spotlight/highlights-africa-2020-elections/#togo)

Cameroon: no presidential election this year, only legislative, so the chief risk is that Biya, who is old and has been rumored to be quite ill at various times, dies in office. Even if he is not in great health, though, that's unlikely to happen in the next 8 months. Throw in a percentage point or two for black swan political events, and I get to something like a 4-percent chance Biya exits office before September. Togo: presidential election in three weeks, with Gnassingbe running for reelection. This is a competitive authoritarian regime, not a democracy (V-Dem electoral democracy index of 0.44 in 2018, the last year available now), so the likelihood that the incumbent loses is generically low. I'm going to peg it at something like 20 percent, which is high for an autocracy, but that V-Dem score is middling. Both: I see these as essentially independent events, so we'd get the probability of them both occurring by multiplying. That gets me to less than 1 percent, which I'll round up to 1.
Yeah, I know--these are pretty weaselly numbers, so I suppose I'll have to do some more research.  This will cut into my nap time.  (My longstanding mantra: "There's a nap for that.")

From the Economist "In ..Togo two generations of the Gnassingbé family have ,,, held the top job since 1967."
Faure Gnassingbé assumed the presidency at a young age on the death of his father in 2005.
"Cameroon, which has been under the thumb of Paul Biya for 37 years, is falling apart while its octogenarian president spends much of his time at ... a Hotel in Geneva."
With no specific insights my forecast will be bland.
